Dear Ms. Klinski:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the manager at 616-552-3662.
Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation In the process of breaking up a fight, Staff 2 grabbed Youth T's
throat causing scratches and neck pain.
Investigation DCWL received this allegation reported by Complainant who is
also Calumet Staff.
I reviewed the facility’s history of licensing violations.
I reviewed the incident report dated 11/2/23 by Supervisor 1. It
was noted Supervisor 1 was not present for the entire incident.
The report indicated Youth T got into a verbal altercation with her
peer. Staff 1 attempted to verbally de-escalate the situation but
was unsuccessful. Youth T assaulted Staff 1 by striking her in the
face. Staff 1 called for assistance and removed herself from the
Pod. Staff 2 and 3 arrived and put the youths in their rooms for
their safety. Youth T kicked her peer’s door; Staff 2 and 3
attempted to verbally deescalate Youth T but were unsuccessful.
Youth T grabbed and pulled Staff 2’s braids. Supervisors 1 and 2
arrived to assist. Supervisor 1 verbally deescalated Youth T until
she released Staff 2’s hair. Youth T was examined by the nurse.
I reviewed photos of Youth T’s neck taken by the Facility Nurse
on 11/3/23. Photos show 1” and ¼” superficial abrasions on her
neck.
I reviewed the medical assessment by Facility Nurse dated
11/3/23. It indicated “Youth T reports neck pain…Per youth, ‘Staff
2 grabbed me by the neck’…Youth reports Staff 2 scratched her
neck and had her hands around the front of her neck and choked
her. Youth then pulled Staff 2’s hair. Youth was then tripped and
pulled to the floor. Superficial abrasions obs (5) to anterior
neck…neck xray (stat) ordered.”
2

I arrived at the facility on 11/07/23 accompanied by Government
Worker 1 and viewed video footage. Video of the entire incident is
described below under additional findings.
In terms of the scratches on Youth T’s neck, the video does not
show Staff 2 grabbing her neck or choking her. It does, however,
show an unidentified staff standing behind and beside Youth T
and wrapping her arm around the youth’s neck holding her for 5
seconds. It is likely the neck scratches were unintentional but
occurred as a result of improper restraint techniques (see
additional finding).
Government Worker 1 interviewed Youth T on 11/03/23 before I
was assigned this investigation. Youth T reported she had been
at the facility for one week and knew Supervisors 1 and 2 were
present but did not know the names of any other staff involved.
Youth T told Government Worker 1 that one staff grabbed her
from behind and scratched her neck with her fingernails, they fell
to the floor and started fighting. She said her hand was sore
because she may have punched a wall when swinging at staff.
Youth T grabbed one staff by her hair. That same staff bent down
and tried to loosen her grip on her hair. She and the staff were
both holding the staff’s hair tugging on it. The supervisors got her
off the staff.
Government Worker 1 observed three scratches. One was
approximately 1 ½” and the other two were ½”. Youth T saw the
nurse and denied any other injuries.
Government Worker 1 requested to Director that Staff 2 not have
contact with Youth T until the investigation is completed.
I interviewed Youth T at the facility on 11/7/23. She refused to
answer any questions because she said she already talked with
Government Worker 1. “I’m sick of talking about it,” she explained
and left the room.
I interviewed Staff 2 jointly with Government Worker 1. She has
worked at the facility for six months and was last trained in
physical management in May 2023. Staff 2’s fingernails were
squared off and manicured with extensions. Asked if she
scratched Youth T’s neck, she responded, “There’s no way
possible I scratched Youth T. I was holding my own hair.”
Government Worker 1 and I interviewed Staff 3 and Staff 4
separately. Both denied that Staff 2 scratched the youth’s neck or
3

held her throat. After the incident, neither staff saw any marks on
Youth T.
I interviewed Supervisor 2 jointly with Government Worker 1.
She said she was present for the incident and was not aware of
any injuries to Youth T.
Government Worker 1 had no findings.
Analysis Photos of Youth T’s neck after the incident showed scratches.
All staff denied scratching Youth T’s neck or seeing another staff
scratch her. Video also does not show the youth’s neck being
scratched. The scratches on her neck were not a form of
punishment but likely occurred as a result of improper restraint
techniques utilized by staff (as cited below).
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Description (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity
of the youth’s behavior, chronological and developmental age,
size, gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and must be done in a manner consistent with the youth’s
treatment plan.
Violation Additional Finding of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff did not follow the procedures for Handle with Care.
Investigation Video of the Girl’s Detention Pod on 11/02/23 (3 min. duration)
All of the youths are in their rooms and five staff are with Youth T
in the living area. Youth T lunges toward Staff 1, pushes her and
reportedly hits her. From behind, another staff person utilizes the
primary restraint technique (PRT), pivots and moves Youth T in
the opposite direction for 3 seconds. Youth struggles, breaks free
from the hold, walks back toward Staff 1 and kicks a door. Three
staff approach her from behind and attempt to restrain her. Youth
T resists, drops her weight, and pulls and backs away from the
staff. Two staff approach her from the front and try to grab her
arms on either side. Youth T resists, drops her weight again and
4

lowers herself to the floor. The two staff initially release her. Then,
rather than back away to safety, Staff 2 bends over and grabs
both of the youth’s arms while another staff holds her feet above
the floor. A third staff moves in and takes Youth T’s right arm.
Youth T is still on the floor and the three staff stand over her
holding her limbs for 2 seconds. At this time, it appears that Youth
T grabs Staff 2’s braids and holds them for 10 seconds.
Supervisor 1 and two more staff arrive on the pod. Several staff
attempt to release the youth’s grip from Staff 2’s hair. After
another 12 seconds, Youth T finally releases the staff’s braids and
remains on the floor, raising and kicking her legs. Five staff stand
over her grabbing at her limbs. Youth T is on the floor for 64 more
seconds but only her feet are in the camera’s view. One by one
staff leave the youth and come back into the camera’s view.
Youth T stands up and walks back toward the staff who just
released her. One staff blocks and holds her again, wraps her left
arm around the front of the youth’s neck from the side and holds
her for 5 seconds. Youth T continues to jump, resist and kicks
over a chair. After 40 more seconds of verbal intervention by
staff, she appears to deescalate.
Staff 1 could not be interviewed. She was suspended from work
for attendance issues and did not respond to voice messages
from Director.
Staff 2 said she and Staff 4 responded to a call for assistance. “I
saw Youth S and T yelling at each other. We cleared the area.
Youth T spazzed out and hit Staff 1 in the face with an open hand.
Youth T acted irate, slipped on the floor, then came for me and
grabbed my hair. I leaned in toward her. She pulled me down by
the hair. I held my hair to keep it from being pulled out. Three
braids were torn out…I couldn’t see who was there to help. I
stepped off the pod. Youth T was still yelling.”
Staff 3 has worked at the facility for six months and was last
trained in physical management in May 2023. She reported “All
the youths were in their rooms and Youth T was yelling on the
pod. Staff stood around her. Youth T reached around staff and
slapped Staff 1 on the side of her face. I was on one side and
Staff 2 was on the other side. We were standing. Youth T
grabbed Staff 2’s hair. I tried to get the braids. Youth T fell. Staff
2 was standing over her. Someone came and tried to help get the
braids loose.” Staff 3 denied holding one of Youth T’s arms and
denied that anyone was holding her feet as seen in the video.
5

Staff 4 has worked at the facility for six months and was last
trained in physical management in April 2023. She said she left
the pod after all the residents except Youth T were in their rooms.
When she returned, she saw Youth T on the floor kicking and
pulling Staff 2’s hair. “Staff 3 untangled Youth T’s hands and
Youth T sat on the floor.” Including herself, Staff 4 said there were
five direct care staff and three supervisors “around” Youth T.
However, she did not hear any supervisor directing the staff what
to do or not to do.
I interviewed Supervisor 1 jointly with Government Worker 1.
She has worked at the facility for five years and was last trained in
physical management in March 2023. When she arrived on the
pod, Supervisor 1 said Youth T had Staff 2’s hair in her hand.
Youth T was on the floor with Staff 2 standing over her. “I was
verbally deescalating and used a defensive move to release Youth
T’s hand. I had Staff 2 step off the pod. Me and Supervisor 2
deescalated Youth T. She apologized to me. We have not let
Staff 2 work with Youth T.”
Supervisor 2 has worked at the facility for one year and was last
trained in physical management in March 2023. She said she and
Supervisor 1 arrived on the pod and tried to release Youth T’s grip
from Staff 2’s hair. “Staff 2 was on the bottom and Youth T was
on top of her. Youth T had two hands full of braids. Staff 3 was
also trying to stop Youth T verbally. Staff 3, Supervisor 1 and I
didn’t touch Youth T. She was enraged.”
I reviewed the facility’s Handle with Care instruction manual.
Holding a youth’s arms and/or feet from a standing position while
the youth lie on her back and wrapping an arm around a youth’s
neck while standing are not approved techniques.
Analysis Video shows improper physical restraint techniques were used.
Staff held a youth’s arms and feet from a standing position while
the youth lie on her back and then while standing one staff
wrapped her arm around the front of the youth’s neck, which are
not approved Handle with Care techniques.
CONSULTATION
Staff call supervisor(s) when the need to physically restrain a
youth is anticipated or in progress. Once supervisor(s) arrive,
their primary role is to coach and direct the staff, which includes
assuring physical restraint(s) are justified and executed properly.
6

Once Youth T lowered herself to the floor, staff should have
backed away to a safe distance. They should not have reengaged
or held her arms or feet. Then after Youth T stood up and
reapproached staff aggressively, staff should have initiated a two-
person control hold or primary restraint technique and should not
have wrapped her arm around the front of the youth’s neck.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Rule Code & Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Description (1) A childcaring institution, including private secure juvenile
justice facilities, shall establish a process improvement and
restraint reduction/elimination plan that:
(a) Includes documentation of each restraint.
Violation Additional Finding of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The incident report does not include documentation of each
restraint (proper or improper).
Investigation Video footage shows Youth T’s free movement was restricted in at
least three instances. One staff used a primary restraint
technique (PRT), three held her arms and feet while she was on
the floor, and another wrapped her arm around the youth’s neck
from a standing position. These restraints were not reflected in
the incident report by Supervisor 1.
I reviewed the facility’s Unusual and Critical Incidents Policy. It
indicates the facility manager or supervisor writes an incident
report summarizing written statements from staff who were
involved or who witnessed the incident.
Analysis The report written by Supervisor 1 focused on Youth T’s behaviors
and verbal interventions by staff but did not include three
instances where staff restricted her free movement (physical
restraint).
CONSULTATION
The difficulty of accurately describing long and complicated
incidents involving eight staff is acknowledged. However, written
7

statements from staff used by supervisors to summarize an event
must include the actions displayed by both the youth(s) and the
staff. All points of physical contact between staff and youth should
be identified to determine if one or more restraints (restriction of
the youth’s movement) occurred, and if the restraints were
justified and executed properly according to Handle with Care
protocol.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Rule Code & Rule 400.4150 Incident reporting
Section (1) Any incident resulting in serious injury of a resident or illness
Description requiring inpatient hospitalization, shall be reported to the parent/
legal guardian, responsible referring agency, and the licensing
authority as soon as possible, but not more than 24 hours after the
incident.
(2) The death of a resident shall be reported immediately to the
parent/legal guardian or next of kin, law enforcement, the licensing
authority, and the referring agency.
(3) If an institution determines that a youth is absent without legal
permission, then the institution shall immediately report the
information to law enforcement, the parent/ legal guardian or next
of kin, the licensing authority, and the referring agency.
(4) When a resident’s behavior results in contact with law
enforcement, the incident shall be reported to the parent/legal
guardian, responsible referring agency, and the licensing authority
as soon as possible, but not more than 24 hours after the incident.
Violation Additional Finding of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The facility’s Unusual and Critical Incident Reporting Policy (Rule
400.4150) is inconsistent with the reporting timeframes required
by the rule and does not include notification to parents/guardians.
8

Investigation The facility’s Unusual and Critical Incident reporting policy is
confusing and insufficient. It combines internal incident report
writing and approval processes with verbal/written notifications to
external sources, i.e. referral sources and licensing.
In terms of the internal incident report writing process, the policy
allows staff to complete and provide written witness statements to
the Supervisor or Facility Manager by the end of their shift (which
could be up to 12 hours after the event). Then the Supervisor or
Facility Manager gathers all of the written statements, summarizes
them, and writes one incident report. By the “next office day”, the
Center Director reviews and signs the report. Including
weekends, holidays, and other days off, the “next office day” could
be up to 5 days after the actual event took place.
In terms of external notifications, the policy indicates if the incident
meets the criteria for reporting to outside sources, the Supervisor
immediately informs the Facility Manager and Center Director.
Incidents requiring external notifications trigger “procedures
outlined in steps H-J,” but there were no such “procedures” found
in this policy. Within 24 hours of the Center Director “being
notified” of the event, Center Director ensures the notifications and
the written incident reports are forwarded to licensing and referral
sources “within the timeframes established by those agencies.”
The licensing rules says notifications are to be immediate or within
no more than 24 hours of the actual event, not within 24 hours of
the Center Director becoming aware of the event. The policy also
does not address how parents/guardians are notified.
Analysis The facility’s procedures for notifying external sources of events
listed in Rule 400.4150 needs to be revised so it is consistent with
the rule.
CONSULTATION
In addition to revising procedures for notifying external sources, I
recommend the facility’s internal incident report writing and
approval process be revised and written on a separate document.
Conclusion Violation Established
9

Rule Code & Rule 400.4163 Health status assessment; notification;
Section debriefing; reporting.
Description (1) The agency shall develop and implement written procedures
for health status screening, notifications, debriefing, and reporting
when a restraint, including an emergency restraint, or seclusion is
used.
Violation Additional Finding of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The agency did not develop and implement written procedures to
facilitate compliance with this rule since it came into effect in May
2022.
Investigation I requested written procedures pertaining to compliance with this
rule and the agency was unable to provide it.
Analysis The agency failed to develop and implement written procedures
for health status screening, notifications, debriefing, and reporting
when a restraint, including an emergency restraint, or seclusion is
used.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
